"What we see. What actually is."

<[silence:2400]>
The gap between perception and reality is like judging a book by its cover—except the cover was drawn by someone who only heard about the story.<[silence:2400]

Our brains fill gaps with guesses.<[silence:1200]>
A stick half-submerged in water looks bent, but it’s straight.<[silence:1200]>
A magician’s trick seems impossible, but it’s just misdirection.<[silence:2400]>

Memory twists facts too.<[silence:1200]>
In one study, people recalled a nonexistent white stripe on a basketball jersey—because they expected it.<[silence:1200]>
Eyewitnesses to the same event describe different details, not because they’re lying, but because perception is a rough sketch, not a photograph.<[silence:2400]>

Even numbers deceive.<[silence:1200]>

"What we see. What actually is. "


The gap between perception and reality is like judging a book by its cover—except the cover was drawn by someone who only heard about the story. <[silence:2400]

Our brains fill gaps with guesses.
A stick half-submerged in water looks bent, but it’s straight.
A magician’s trick seems impossible, but it’s just misdirection.

Memory twists facts too.
In one study, people recalled a nonexistent white stripe on a basketball jersey—because they expected it.
Eyewitnesses to the same event describe different details, not because they’re lying, but because perception is a rough sketch, not a photograph.

Even numbers deceive.
A 99-cent price feels cheaper than $1, though the difference is a penny.
A "90% fat-free" label sounds healthy—until you realize it’s also "10% fat. "

The gap isn’t a flaw.
It’s how we survive.
Our brains prioritize speed over accuracy—like a smartphone lowering resolution to save battery.
But the cost?
Sometimes, we mistake the map for the territory.


Cognitive biases.
The placebo effect.
How cameras lie.
